reviews.review_msg: She's a TA for cmns 304 and was terrible at providing any helpful feedback to improve in the course. She doesn't explain things very well. Expects students to do all the work in the class. Would not recommend. Difficult marker and provides no justification :(

I disagree with the other one. Clayton was totally helpful TA, very approachable and  friendly with students, edgy sense of humour and funny stories. He pushes your boundaries and challenges you to think. I went to him several times for help with my assignments, essays he was always helpful. I wish I could say the same for the prof. This course suc

I think Andrew is an amazing instructor, he did great work. He made the course very interesting and engaging. I have learned lots from it! I appreciate him explaining the ideas with concrete examples and also his own perspectives. I am an extremely emulative person, and his thoughts were a significant path for me in the future!
Andrew recorded awesome lectures! He and the TA gave me helpful feedback on my assignments. Really enjoyed the course. Be prepared to write tho
very unclear instructions, the way he and TA marked did not follow the instructions.

One of the coolest prof I ever had lol. I'm graduating next semester and regret that I did not take his classes sooner. Will definitely re-take his class if I have a chance. Funny and caring with examples that get us through a dry writing class. If you like Stephen Zilwood, you will definitely like his teaching style.

This is for CMNS 315 and not 304. The prof is so disorganised, the layout of the class kept changing every week. The weekly participation was initially online, then it was in class on paper at the beginning of lecture and the following week it was at the end of the lecture. Lectures are not engaging at all. Would not recommend.

Easily the worst instructor. She's lazy and unprepared and doesn't even lecture, she just pads time by asking vague questions that the same 2 students answer over and over. She's antagonistic towards students, doesn't share lecture slides with us, she didn't even bother to show us the grading rubric for assignments before we submitted them. Avoid!
Class is lecture heavy. Personally, I found it difficult to connect the lectures to the course readings. Speaks awfully slow and has stale humor. Assignments and exam are vague.

Terry is funny and inspiring. His lecture-style can be a little bit eccentric, but I thought that was appropriate given how the entire course is based on the premise of getting you to think outside the box. I'd take Terry any day over a standard, read-off-the-powerpoint professor.

Terry is a nice guy and he is willing to take a look at paper drafts and tell you where you can improve.  That said, I couldn't really follow his lecture style as he presented a new, unrelated topic each week (medical discourse, religious discourse, etc) which was very different than what I expected from the course title.

He's bit eccentric, and his outside-the-box approach to the course left a few people scratching their heads (but those people could use a little shaking up.)  Academia needs more people like this who aren't just spewing the standard fare to be repeated back to them on exams. If you can get over his slight creepy uncle vibe, you'll be glad you came.

Terry was just OK in my opinion. He seems like a genuinely really nice guy who is unquestionably passionate about what he teaches, but I honestly found the whole concept of the course a bit of a stretch. Most of the time I felt like he was just making stuff up. I ended up with a good grade but can confidently say that I have no idea what I learned.

Terry is a great prof, who appears knowledgeable and passionate about the content he teaches. Assignments are fair, and the in-class essay was an open-book test. Overall an interesting class and I enjoyed the lectures.

I do not understand why Terry's mark is so low. He is brillant, funny and interresting. I agree three hours lecture is intense but if you participate and do the readings, you will enjoy his lectures. I intend to take more courses with him, if I can.

This class puzzled me at first, and I felt very lost- but I think I know why. In many CMNS courses, you are expected to regurgitate, and that is what many CMNS students are trained to do. This course's content, however, is very much open to interpretation and you take away your own meaning. I think you should take this class, don't be scared off.

Couldn't link readings to the lecture without the TAs help. Papers are given without very many guidelines, which makes it hard to know what they're looking for, resulting in lower grades because they mark hard. TA (DYLAN) WAS HORRIBLE WITH PROVIDING FEEDBACK IN A TIMELY FASHION. Get 2 TAs? Can't seem to keep up with the marking. Don't take it.
AWESOME lecturer, had me engaged the whole three hours every time. Brings familiar things like a Hendrix song or an Orson Wells film into context in a way that makes you see things differently.
Good prof. Quite difficult but him and TA are willing to help. You learn a lot new concepts in this class.

Terry teaches concepts. You couldn't cheat in this class if you tried. If you are interested in doing graduate school then take a class from Terry.. Encyclopaedic knowledge of Social thinkers/theories from the past 200 years. The most important thing you will learn from Terry is how to make connections from abstractions and relate them to real life

The worst class ever. Instead of list this class as communication course, I think its more like a philosophy class. The course materials are super dry and doesnt make any sense! I cant see how it connects to EVERYDAY LIFE COMMUNICATION. Anyways, do your work you will be fine. I hope someone else can teach this class.

Terry is very passionate and genuine. The course covers a lot of topics that seem unrelated but he brings them all together in a really interesting way. He can be hard to follow sometimes but always is super helpful and willing to clarify. If you engage in the course and pay attention to what he mentions in lectures you'll be golden!

Terry is fantastic. He's a great speaker and always makes an effort to make his lectures more interactive. If you're looking to take only one of 323 or 304, I would definitely choose 304, as long as Terry's still teaching it. It's a great primer for a lot of other upper division CMNS courses.

I was not looking forward to this class from reading comments here, however, after a great semester I absolutely can't understand what everyone's problem is. Terry is a great prof, very dynamic and enthusiastic. He is clear, has good notes but also expects alot from his students - as he should, it's a 3rd yr class! Julie (TA) is awesome too!

This class has nothing to do with "everyday communication" at all. I am so confused 99% of the time and I honestly never know what the relevance of what he talks about to the course is. Brutal class with so much writing. The readings are so dry as well.

Totally boring and confusing. I tried looking up concepts he talked about and they seem non-existent. Little structure to class. Never missed a class, but not really sure what it was about. Don't take this class! It is nothing like what it sounds like it is about.
Super interesting classes. The class is a bit mind boggling (in a good way). Definitely take it if you like being critical of every aspect of daily life. Great class. Fantastic TA (Angela Gunther).

Dr. Hauck knows what he's talking about, that's for sure. However, I don't think his specialities were highlighted in the format of an online class. Only copied and pasted text from the readings in his slides, which made it really difficult to stay engaged. Tons of readings and homework. Take another W class if you have to.

Important Notes: 
- If you can, do NOT take this class (or any) at 8:30 AM.
- Passionate prof and entertaining lectures
- Heavy on theory and lots of readings, but he explains them well. Do not skip, as it's hard to grasp content on your own. 
- Pop quizzes on readings
- Grading can be difficult ngl
- Prof is genuine, understanding, and empathetic

He's a funny & friendly guy who is clearly passionate about the topic, but he seems to have a very philosophical approach to communications which made things a bit more confusing than they needed to be. Lectures were boring in my opinion, but the assignments were really easy. Lots of readings too but you can follow along fine w/o them
Honestly, one of the best profs in SFU CMNS, everyone should take this course with him.
Grading criteria was super unclear even though I asked a ton of questions. TA wasn't helpful at all. Lectures weren't super interesting. Would avoid this prof.

For a sessional lecturer he's hands down one of the best teachers in the whole program. The way he engages with student participation and questions beats a lot of profs in the program and it's really clear he deserves a bigger role. enjoyed the course and others shared the same opinion, enjoy the philosophy edge he brings.
Good prof. Lectures can be sorta hard to follow but he gets really into them.
A very nice professor! Would take his course again!

Steven is so passionate in his lectures. He has a tendency to be a bit all over the place but you learn so much if you pay attention and get involved. His office hours are also super helpful and he'll stay so late after lecture to help out his students. He really cares about all of his students and wants them to do well in his class!
never take this course with him! He is confusing and also a tough grader. His TA doesn't look like they want to teach the tutorial. Didn't learn anything from this course.
worst professor ever. Only reads from the PPT and a very tough grader.

Steven Malcic was a decent prof. All assignments are graded by the TA so your grade is dependent on whether or not they are a tough grader. Steven is a bit weird and has a strange approach to teaching. This was a writing heavy course so I don't recommend it if it's not mandatory for you.
